[[File:Hollinger box (angle view).jpg|thumb|Hollinger box (angle view)]]
A '''Hollinger box''', also known as a "document box" or "archives box," is a specially constructed cardboard box used in [[archives]] for [[Preservation_%28library_and_archival_science%29|preservation]] of documents and photographs. The term "Hollinger" refers to the manufacturer, Hollinger Metal Edge, a company founded in 1945 in [[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington, Virginia]]. Hollinger Metal Edge worked with officials at the [[Library of Congress]] and [[National Archives and Records Administration|National Archives]] of the United States to develop acid free papers, storage boxes and envelopes that would preserve archival collections.<ref>http://www.hollingermetaledge.com/modules/cms/index.html?pageID=9 "Our History," Hollinger Metal Edge Company</ref> The boxes are designed for long-term storage, and typically rest on standard [[Bookcase#Library shelving|library shelving]].
The [[Society of American Archivists]] defines it as a "container that holds folders containing paper documents vertically and that measures roughly 10 inches high, 12 or 15 inches wide, and 6 or 3 inches deep, and that usually has an integral top hinged at the upper back."<ref>http://www2.archivists.org/glossary/terms/d/document-box</ref>

[[Dos Pilas]] | excavations = 1937, 1984–1986, 1997 | archaeologists = Edwin Shook, Antonia Foias | architectural_styles = Classic Maya | architectural_details = | notes = | designation1 = | designation1_offname = | designation1_type = | designation1_criteria = | designation1_date = | delisted1_date = | designation1_partof = | designation1_number = | designation1_free1name = | designation1_free1value = | designation1_free2name = | designation1_free2value = | designation1_free3name = | designation1_free3value = | designation2 = | designation2_offname = | designation2_type = | designation2_criteria = | designation2_date = | delisted2_date = | designation2_partof = | designation2_number = | designation2_free1name = | designation2_free1value = | designation2_free2name = | designation2_free2value = | designation2_free3name = | designation2_free3value = | precolumbian = yes }} {{Maya civilization}} '''La Amelia''' is a [[Pre-Columbian]] [[Maya civilization|Maya]] archaeological site near [[Itzan]], in the lower [[Pasión River]] region of the [[Petén Department]] of [[Guatemala]]. It formed a [[polity]] in the [[Mesoamerican chronology|Late Classic]] (AD 600 to 830), and was involved in the war between [[Tikal]] and [[Calakmul]] followed, in 650, by La Amelia's takeover by [[Dos Pilas]]. Two centuries of intermittent warfare followed until the area's population was so diminished by about 830, that this is considered the beginning of abandonment of Classic sites in the region. ==Location== La Amelia is located on a series of low hills in the [[Municipalities of Guatemala|municipality]] of [[Sayaxché]], {{convert|4|km|mi}} south of La Florida and the [[Pasión River]]. The site sits at a level of {{convert|150|to|160|m|ft}} [[above mean sea level]]. The low-lying areas around the hills are prone to flooding.Ortiz de León 2004 The main site area is maintained as a forest park by the nearby village of San Francisco El Tumbo. More than 90 percent of the mounds at the site have been looted.Foias 1997 ==History== La Amelia was a subordinate site in the Classic Period [[Petexbatún]] kingdom of Mutal that was first ruled from [[Dos Pilas]] and then from [[Aguateca]].Sharer & Traxler 2006, p. 409. The site is located to the northwest of Dos Pilas, and may have originally been called B'ahlam.Guenter, p.21 The rapidly expanding Dos Pilas kingdom conquered La Amelia in the early 8th century.Demarest et al 1991, p.229 The occupational history of La Amelia appears to have been brief and limited to the Late Classic.Ortiz de León 2004, p.21. In AD 802 the last known ruler of the kingdom, [[Tan Te' K'inich]], supervised a ritual conducted by the ruler of La Amelia, [[Lachan K'awiil Ajaw Bot]], the last reference anywhere to Tan Te' K'inich.Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.409 Lachan K'awiil Ajaw Bot, the local La Amelia king, is depicted on La Amelia Panel 2, dated to AD 804 and continued to raise monuments at the site, the last of which that can be dated was erected in 807 and contains the last reference to the Petexbatún kingdom of Mutal.Martin & Grube 2000, p. 65 Lachan K'awiil Ajaw Bot is also mentioned on Panel 1 and Hieroglyphic Stairway 1 at the site. He is known to have been born on 25 June 760 and to have been enthroned on 1 May 802.Martin & Grube 2000, p. 65 La Amelia was abandoned some time in the middle of the 9th century AD.Ortiz de León 2004, pp.21-22. ===Modern history=== The [[Carnegie Institution]] carried out investigations at the site in 1937. That project documented several carved stone monuments, and created a partial site map which was published by [[Sylvanus Morley]] in his 1938 volume ''The Inscriptions of Peten''.Morley 1938 [[Yale University]] carried out further investigations from 1984 to 1986.Ortiz de León 2004, p.21. A mapping and excavation project was conducted at the site by the La Amelia Archaeological Project in 1997. That work was directed by Dr. Antonia Foias of [[Williams College]]. During the summer 1997 field season, the La Amelia Archaeological Project completed mapping of the central site area and excavated several test units.Foias 1997 ==The site== La Amelia is a small site covering an area of approximately {{convert|0.74|km2|sqmi}}. The site is divided into four groups, two of which have monumental architecture, and a further 13 smaller residential groups.Ortiz de León 2004, p.21. The 1997 mapping project recorded a total of 71 structures at the site.Foias 1997 The central plaza area appears to have been focused around the "Group of the Three Pyramids" in the southern portion of the site. That group included three pyramids of between {{convert|3|and|8|m|ft}} in height, all of which have been severely damaged by looter trenches.Foias 1997 The "Group of the Hieroglyphic Stairway" is situated {{convert|0.5|km|mi}}north of the main plaza, in the northwest quadrant of the site, and was constructed principally by terracing and flattening the summit of a natural hill.Foias 1997 This group exhibits three frontal terraces, and an interior courtyard on the summit which is surrounded by six narrow range structures. Access to the lowest terrace is achieved via a 5-step monolithic stairway featuring limestone blocks carved with glyphs and scenes. Two carved panels (called alternately '''Stela 1''' and '''Panel 2''') originally decorated the front of the structure to either side of the stairway.Foias 1997 ===Monuments=== [[Image:LA AMELIA STEP 7.jpg|left|250px|thumb|Step 7 from the Hieroglyphic Stairway]] When [[Edwin M. Shook]] of the [[Carnegie Institution]] first documented the site of La Amelia in 1937, he noted the presence of six [[hieroglyphic]] blocks which functioned as risers along the uppermost level of the monolithic stairway.Morley 1937 This led him to identify the '''Hieroglyphic Stairway''' at the site, and to name the associated architectural group accordingly. A seventh carved block was recovered in 1997 from a test unit excavated on the plaza immediately southwest of the staircase.Foias 1997 Three of the carved stones from the Hieroglyphic Stairway were entirely glyphic, while the four remaining stones (including the one recovered in 1997) feature reclining male figures along with short texts.Foias 1997 Stephen Houston documented one of the three glyphic stones, although no record exists of the other two.Houston 1993 Shook sketched the three steps he saw that depicted human figures, but did not include any details regarding the glyphic texts on those stones.Morley 1937 None of the six steps recorded by Shook remained ''[[in situ]]'' by 1997, and their ultimate disposition is unknown.Foias 1997 The four carved steps featuring human figures from the Hieroglyphic Stairway at La Amelia all display images of simply-dressed males, who were likely ancestors of the site's ruler.Foias 1997 All four of these figures hold heads or masks of [[God K]]. The panel discovered in 1997 included a [[Calendar Round]] date of 2 Caban 2 Muan, and an associated text describing a ritual involving God K which took place on that date. The emblem glyph for the figure on this panel may be that of [[Tamarindito]].Foias 1997 The carved panels which originally flanked the Hieroglyphic Stairway at La Amelia depict dancing rulers in full ceremonial costume, as well as glyphic texts. A lower register on each monument depicts a reclining [[jaguar]] which looks up at the dancing ruler.Morley 1938; Houston 1993 '''Panel 2''' records a date of AD 804 and depicts the ruler Lachan K'awiil Ajaw Bot dressed as a ballplayer.Martin & Grube 2000; Zender 2004 Panel 2 now resides in front of the Mayor's building in Sayaxché. '''Stela 1''' was originally located west of the Hieroglyphic Stairway and records a date of AD 807.Tourtellot & González 2005 Stela 1 now resides at the National Museum of Anthropology and Ethnology in [[Guatemala City]]. ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} ==References== {{Refbegin|indent=yes}} : {{Cite journal |author=Demarest, Arthur A. |authorlink=Arthur Demarest |author2=Stephen Houston |author3=Kevin Johnston |year=1991 |title=Proyecto Arqueológico Petexbatun: Nuevas perspectivas sobre el sistema de guerra Maya y el colapso |journal=II Simposio de Investigaciones Arqueológicas en Guatemala, 1988 (edited by J.P. {{multiple issues| {{essay-like|date=February 2016}} {{expert needed|1=Linguistics|date=February 2016}} {{original research|date=February 2016}} {{Orphan|date=February 2016}} }} The question whether the use of language influences [[spatial cognition]] is closely related to theories of [[linguistic relativity]]—also known as the [[Sapir-Whorf hypothesis]]—which states that the structure of a language affects cognitive processes of the speaker. Debates about this topic are mainly focused on the extent to which language influences spatial cognition or if it does at all. Research also concerns differences between perspectives on spatial relations across [[cultures]], what these imply, and the exploration of potentially partaking cognitive mechanisms.
==Frames of reference across cultures== Research shows that frames of reference for spatial cognition differ across cultures and that language could play a crucial role in structuring these different frames.<ref name="Majid, 2004">{{cite journal|last1=Majid, Bowerman, Kita, Haun, & Levinson|title=Can language restructure cognition? The case for space|journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences|date=2004|volume=8|issue=3|pages=108–114|doi=10.1016/j.tics.2004.01.003}}</ref> Three types of perspectives on space can be distinguished:<ref name="Majid, 2004"/> * The '''Relative''' perspective (dominant in [[Dutch language|Dutch]], [[English language|English]], and [[Japanese language|Japanese]]) is dependent on the viewer's position towards the object and often uses descriptions like "the object is to the left/right of ...". * The '''Absolut''' perspective (found in speakers of [[Arrernte language|Arrernte]], [[Guugu Yimithirr language|Guugu Yimithirr]], [[Kuuk Thaayore]], and [[Tzeltal language|Tzeltal]]) is based on cardinal directions such as north, east, south, and west. Therefore, the description of the location of an object does not change according to the position towards it. * The '''Intrinsic''' perspective (found in speakers of [[Mopan language|Mopan]] and [[Totonac]]) describes the location of an object without referring to yourself or the use of cardinal directions. Instead it uses the relation towards another object to specify spatial relations (e.g. "the object is at the back/front/side of ..."). Languages like English or Dutch do not exclusively make use of relative descriptions but these appear to be most frequent compared to intrinsic or absolute descriptions. An absolute frame of reference is usually restricted to large scale geographical descriptions in these languages. Speakers of the [[Australian]] languages [[Arrernte language|Arrernte]], [[Guugu Yimithirr language|Guugu Yimithirr]], and [[Kuuk Thaayore]] only use absolute descriptions.<ref name="Majid, 2004" /> The relative and intrinsic perspectives seem to be connected as there is no known language which applies only one of these frames of reference exclusively.<ref name="Levinson, 2003">{{cite book|last1=Levinson|title=Space in Language and Cognition: Explorations in Cognitive Diversity|date=2003|publisher=Cambridge University Press}}</ref><ref name="Pederson, 2003">{{cite book|last1=Pederson|title=Spatial Cognition III: Routes and Navigation, Human Memory and Learning, Spatial Representation and Spatial Learning|date=2003|publisher=Springer Verlag|pages=287–304}}</ref>
==Two views on spatial cognition== (1.) It has been argued that people universally use an [[egocentric]] representation to solve non-linguistic spatial tasks which would align with the relative frame of reference.<ref name="Wang, 2002">{{cite book|last1=Wang & Spelke|title=Human spatial representation: insights from animals|date=2002|pages=376–382}}</ref> (2.) Other researchers have proposed that people apply multiple frames of reference during their daily lives and that languages reflect these cognitive structures.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gallistel|title=Language and spatial frames of reference in mind and brain|journal=Trends Cogn. Sci.|date=2002|volume=6|pages=321–322|doi=10.1016/s1364-6613(02)01962-9}}</ref> In the light of the current body of literature the second view seems to be the more plausible one.<ref name="Levinson, 2003"/><ref name="Levinson, 2002">{{cite journal|last1=Levinson|title=Returning the tables: language affects spatial reasoning|journal=Cognition|date=2002|volume=84|pages=155–188|doi=10.1016/s0010-0277(02)00045-8}}</ref><ref name="Pederson, 1998">{{cite journal|last1=Pederson|title=Semantic typology and spatial conceptualization|journal=Language|date=1998|volume=74|pages=557–589|doi=10.1353/lan.1998.0074}}</ref><ref name="Wassmann & Dasen">{{cite journal|last1=Wassmann & Dasen|title=Balinese spatial orientation: some empirical evidence of moderate linguistic relativity|journal=J. R. Anthropol. Inst|date=1998|volume=4|pages=689–711|doi=10.2307/3034828}}</ref>
==Directional gestures== The dominant frames of reference have found to be reflected in the common types of [[gesticulation]] in the respective language.<ref name=McNeill>{{cite book|last1=McNeill|title=Hand and Mind|date=1992|publisher=Chicago University Press}}</ref> Speakers of absolute languages would typically represent an object moving north with a hand movement towards the north.<ref name="Haviland, 1993">{{cite journal|last1=Haviland|title=Anchoring, iconicity, and orientation in GuuguYimithirr pointing gestures|journal=J. Linguist. Anthropol.|date=1993|volume=3|pages=3–45|doi=10.1525/jlin.1993.3.1.3}}</ref><ref name="Haviland, 1998">{{cite journal|last1=Haviland|title=Guugu Yimithirr cardinal directions|journal=Ethos|date=1998|volume=26|pages=25–47|doi=10.1525/eth.1998.26.1.25}}</ref> Whereas speakers of relative languages typically depict a movement of an object to the right with a hand movement to the right, independent of the direction they are facing during speech.<ref name="Kita, 2003">{{cite journal|last1=Kita & Özyürek|title=What does cross-linguistic variation in semantic coordination of speech and gesture reveal? Evidence for an interface representation of spatial thinking and speaking|journal=J. Mem. Lang.|date=2003|volume=48|pages=16–32|doi=10.1016/s0749-596x(02)00505-3}}</ref> Speakers of intrinsic languages would, for example, typically represent human movement from the perspective of the mover with a [[sagittal]] hand gesture away from the speaker.<ref name="kita, 2001">{{cite book|last1=Kita|title=Cultural speciﬁcity of spatial schemas as manifested in spontaneous gestures|date=2001|publisher=MIT Press|pages=115–146}}</ref>
==The spatial representation of time== A study by Boroditsky and Gaby<ref name="Boroditsky, 2010">{{cite journal|last1=Boroditsky & Gaby|title=Remembrances of times east: Absolute spatial representations of time in an aboriginal Australian community|journal=Psychological Science|date=2010|volume=21|pages=1635–1639|doi=10.1177/0956797610386621|pmid=20959511}}</ref> compared speakers of an absolute language—[[Pormpuraawans]]—with English speakers. The task on which they compared them consisted of the spatial arrangement of cards which showed a temporal progression. The result was that the speakers of the relative language (Americans) exclusively chose to represent time spatially as progressing from left (earlier time) to right (later time). Whereas the [[Pormpuraawans]] took the direction they faced into account and preferred to depict time as progressing from east (earlier time) to west (later time) the most.
==Third variables== [[Confounding variables]] could potentially explain a significant proportion of the measured difference in performance between the linguistic frames of reference. These can be categorized into three types of confounding factors: * '''Environmental factors''' (e.g. rural vs. urban or open terrain vs. dense forest) could influence linguistic and non-linguistic categories.<ref name="Li, 2002">{{cite journal|last1=Li & Gleitman|title=Turning the tables: language and spatial reasoning|journal=Cognition|date=2002|volume=83|pages=265–294|doi=10.1016/s0010-0277(02)00009-4}}</ref><ref name="Lindsey, 2002">{{cite journal|last1=Lindsey & Brown|title=Color naming and the phototoxic effects of sunlight on the eye|journal=Psychol. Sci.|date=2002|volume=13|pages=506–512|doi=10.1111/1467-9280.00489}}</ref> * '''Global cognitive styles''' (e.g. [[individualism]] vs. [[collectivism]]) could act as a [[:wikt:mediator|mediator]] between language and cognition.<ref name="Greenfield, 2003">{{cite journal|last1=Greenﬁeld|title=Cultural pathways through universal development|journal=Annu. Rev. Psychol.|date=2003|volume=54|pages=461–490}}</ref> * '''Differences in habitual action''' (could be reflected in subsistence patterns) might shape the differing use of frames of reference in language and cognition.<ref name=Gallistel>{{cite journal|last1=Gallistel|title=Conception, perception and the control of action. Reply to Majid.|journal=Trends Cogn. Sci.|date=2002|volume=6|page=504|doi=10.1016/s1364-6613(02)02033-8}}</ref>
===The importance of language for cognition=== Gentner, Özyürek, Gürcanli, and Goldin-Meadow<ref name="Gentner, 2013">{{cite journal|last1=Gentner, Özyürek, Gürcanli, and Goldin-Meadow|title=Spatial language facilitates spatial cognition: Evidence from children who lack language input|journal=Cognition|date=2013|volume=127|issue=3|pages=318–330|doi=10.1016/j.cognition.2013.01.003|pmid=23542409|pmc=3708650}}</ref> found that deaf children, who lacked a conventional language, did not use gestures to convey spatial relations (see [[home sign]]). Building on that, they showed that deaf children performed significantly worse on a task of spatial cognition compared to hearing children. They concluded that the acquisition of (spatial) language is an important factor in shaping spatial cognition.
==Cognitive mechanisms== Several mechanisms accounting for or contributing to the possible effect of language on cognition have been suggested: *'''Perceptual tuning and attention''': Experience (with language) can direct habitual attention so that perception becomes more oriented towards particular features in the environment.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Goldstone|title=Perceptual learning|journal=Annu. Rev. Psychol.|date=1998|volume=49|pages=585–612|doi=10.1146/annurev.psych.49.1.585}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sloutsky|title=The role of similarity in the development of categorization|journal=Trends Cogn. Sci.|date=2003|volume=7|pages=246–251|doi=10.1016/s1364-6613(03)00109-8}}</ref> *'''[[The novice-expert shift]]''': Increased experience in a specific domain can lead to a recoding of representational units.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bailenson|title=A bird’s eye view: biological categorization and reasoning within and across cultures.|journal=Cognition|date=2002|volume=84|pages=1–53|doi=10.1016/s0010-0277(02)00011-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ross|title=Cultural and experiential differences in the development of folkbiological induction|journal=Cogn. Dev.|date=2003|volume=18|pages=25–47|doi=10.1016/s0885-2014(02)00142-9}}</ref> *'''Structure-mapping''': When comparing conceptual representations based on similarities, language can influence what tends to be compared to what by promoting the saliency of specific categories.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bowerman & Choi|title=Space under construction: language-speciﬁc spatial categorization in ﬁrst language acquisition|date=2003|publisher=MIT Press|pages=387–427}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Gentner|title=Why we’re so smart|date=2003|publisher=MIT Press|pages=195–235}}</ref> *'''Costs of computation''': Based on the assumption of language promoting the formation of different categories, it would result that the cognitive effort to access the more salient frame of reference in the respective language (relative, absolute or intrinsic) is lower in comparison to switching to another frame.<ref name="Levinson, 2003" /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hunt & Agnoli|title=The Whorﬁan hypothesis: a cognitive psychology perspective|journal=Psychol. Rev.|date=1991|volume=98|pages=377–389|doi=10.1037/0033-295x.98.3.377}}</ref>
==References== <references />
[[Category:Cognition]] [[Category:Psycholinguistics]]

The official '''language of Illinois''' is [[English language|English]]. Nearly 80% of the population speak English natively, and most others speak it fluently as a second language. The forms of [[American English]] spoken in [[Illinois]] range from [[Inland Northern American English|Inland Northern]] near Chicago and the northern part of the state, to [[Midland American English|Midland]] and [[Southern American English|Southern]] dialects further [[Downstate Illinois|downstate]]. Illinois has speakers of many other languages, of which [[Spanish language|Spanish]] is by far the most widespread. Illinois's indigenous languages disappeared when the Indian population was deported under the policy of [[Indian Removal]]. ==Official language== English is Illinois's [[official language]]. Illinois was one of the first states in America to pass an official language law, though its first official language was not English but "American". In 1923, Representative [[Washington J. McCormick]] of [[Montana]] had failed to pass a bill in the United States Congress declaring "American" to be the official language of the United States. Following the bill's failure, Senator Frank Ryan introduced a similar bill to the [[Illinois General Assembly]]. The bill passed with the support of Irish and Jewish politicians in [[Chicago]], who, by rejecting the term "English", wanted to show their opposition to British policies in [[Ireland]] and [[Mandatory Palestine|Palestine]], respectively.{{cite web |url=http://www.english.illinois.edu/-people-/faculty/debaron/essays/langlaw.htm |title=Language Laws and Related Court Decisions |last1=Baron |first1=Dennis |authorlink=Dennis Baron |date=n.d. |website=Dennis Baron: Professor of English and linguistics |publisher=[[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] Department of English |accessdate=30 March 2014 }} In 1969, another act of the General Assembly replaced "American" with "English." Meanwhile, the term "American language" survives in some legislation from the period.For example, {{ILCS|225|705|27.01}} Unlike [[English-only movement|official language laws]] in many other states, the statute in Illinois is purely symbolic, having the same status as laws naming [[List of Illinois state symbols|state symbols]] like the state bird and state fossil.{{cite book |last=Baron |first=Dennis |authorlink=Dennis Baron |year=2001 |chapter=Language Legislation and Language Abuse: American Language Policy through the 1990s |editor1-last=Dueñas González |editor1-first=Roseann |editor2-last=Melis |editor2-first=Ildikó |title=Language Ideologies: Critical Perspectives on the Official English Movement |volume=2: History, Theory, and Policy |location=Mahwah, New Jersey |publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum Associates |isbn=0-8058-4054-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Dce2AgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=30 March 2014 }} ==Dialects of English== The English of Illinois varies from [[Inland Northern American English|Inland Northern]] in the northern part of the state, to [[Midland American English|Midland]] and [[Southern American English|Southern]] further south. The [[Northern Cities Vowel Shift]] is advanced in Chicago and its vicinity, and some features of the shift can be heard along The St. Louis Corridor, a southwestern extension of the NCVS stretching from the Chicago area to [[St. Louis]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ling.upenn.edu/Events/PLC/plc36/abstracts/Friedman_PLC36.pdf |title=A Northern Cities Shift Retreat in the St. Louis Corridor |last1=Friedman |first1=Lauren |year=2012 |website=36th Annual Penn Linguistics Colloquium |publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania]] |accessdate=16 February 2015}} The distribution of dialect features reflects the origins of early English-speaking settlers: Inland Northern predominates in areas first settled by people from [[New England]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[Pennsylvania]], and [[Germany]]; Midland and Southern are spoken in areas settled by people from the [[southern United States]].{{cite journal |last=Frazer |first=Timothy C. |year=2007 |title=Tongue ties: The linguistic map of western Illinois |url=http://www.lib.niu.edu/2007/ih070512.html |journal=Illinois Heritage |publisher=[[Illinois State Historical Society]] |location=Springfield |volume=10 |issue=3 |pages=12–15 |accessdate=30 March 2014}} [[African American Vernacular English]] is also spoken in parts of the state. ==Other languages== As of 2010, 78.26% (9,315,206) of Illinois residents age 5 and older spoke English at home as a [[primary language]], while 12.74% (1,516,674) spoke [[Spanish language|Spanish]], 1.64% (195,600) [[Polish language|Polish]], 0.67% (80,954) [[Chinese language|Chinese]] (which includes [[Cantonese]] and [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]]), and 0.64% (75,754) [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]]. In total, 21.74% (2,587,254) of Illinois's population age 5 and older spoke a [[mother language]] other than English.{{cite web|url=http://www.mla.org/cgi-shl/docstudio/docs.pl?map_data_results |title=Illinois |publisher=[[Modern Language Association]] |accessdate=August 11, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130815140430/http://www.mla.org/cgi-shl/docstudio/docs.pl?map_data_results |archivedate=August 15, 2013 |df= }} Among those who speak a language other than English at home, most (57.3%) were reported in 2010 to speak English "very well." 20.7% spoke English "well," 15.9% spoke it "not well," and only 6.2% "not at all".{{cite web |url=https://www.census.gov/prod/2013pubs/acs-22.pdf |title=Language Use in the United States: American Community Survey Reports |last1=Ryan |first1=Camille |date=August 2013 |website=Census.gov |publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]] |accessdate=30 March 2014 }} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin-left:1em; float:center" |+ '''Top 10 Non-English Languages Spoken in Illinois''' |- ! Language !! Percentage of population
(as of 2010) |- | [[Spanish language|Spanish]] || 12.74% |- | [[Polish language|Polish]] || 1.64% |- | [[Chinese language|Chinese]] (including [[Cantonese]] and [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]]) || 0.67% |- | [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] || 0.64% |- | [[German language|German]] and [[Korean language|Korean]] (tied) || 0.41% |- | [[Arabic language|Arabic]] || 0.38% |- | [[Urdu language|Urdu]] and [[Russian language|Russian]] (tied) || 0.35% |- | [[Italian language|Italian]] || 0.34% |- | [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] || 0.32% |- | [[Greek language|Greek]] and [[Hindi language|Hindi]] (tied) || 0.30% |} In the colonial period, the [[Miami-Illinois language]] was spoken throughout the territory of the modern state. [[Jacques Gravier]], a missionary at [[Starved Rock]], wrote the first French-Illinois dictionary in 1700; Jean Le Boullenger wrote another in 1725.{{cite web |url=http://www.museum.state.il.us/muslink/nat_amer/post/htmls/id_lang.html |title=The Illinois Identity: Language |year= 2000|website=MuseumLink Illinois |publisher=Illinois State Museum |accessdate=30 March 2014 }} Other indigenous languages at the time of statehood in 1818 included [[Potawatomi language|Potawatomi]], [[Fox language|Sauk-Fox]], and [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]]. These languages disappeared from Illinois when the U.S. carried out [[Indian Removal]], culminating in the [[Black Hawk War]] of 1832 and the [[Treaty of Chicago#1833 Treaty of Chicago|Second Treaty of Chicago]] in 1833. [[French language|French]] was the language of [[Illinois Country|colonial Illinois]] before 1763, and under British rule remained the most-spoken language in the main settlements of [[Cahokia, Illinois|Cahokia]] and [[Kaskaskia, Illinois|Kaskaskia]]. Many French speakers left Illinois after it came under U.S. control following the [[Illinois Campaign]] of 1778, but Illinois was still a bilingual territory for several more years before the flood of Anglo-American settlers overwhelmed the old communities.{{cite book |last=Boggess |first=Arthur Clinton |year=1908 |title=The Settlement of Illinois 1778-1830 |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/34049/34049-pdf.pdf |location=Chicago |publisher=[[Chicago Historical Society]] |page=50 |isbn= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170516010101/http://www.gutenberg.org/files/34049/34049%2Dpdf.pdf|archivedate=2010 |dead-url=yes |accessdate=30 March 2014 }} By the time of statehood in 1818, French was in decline for matters of politics and government.Boggess, 135 Colonial French died out in Illinois but survived as [[Missouri French]] in some communities across the Mississippi River.{{cite journal |last=O'Connor |first=Rorye |date=15 November 2012 |title=French still thrives in the Illinois territory |url=http://www.register-news.com/x1988173620/French-still-thrives-in-the-Illinois-territory |journal=[[Mt. Vernon Register-News]] |location=Mt. Vernon, Illinois |publisher= |accessdate=30 March 2014 }} The 2010 census reported 34,938 French speakers in Illinois, 0.29% of the population. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Illinois}} {{Languages of the United States}} [[Category:Illinois culture]] [[Category:Languages of the United States|Illinois]]

Tatiana Izmailova |doctoral_students = |known_for = "The Art of the 13th century Armenian Painter Grigor Tsaghkogh" 1
"The Art of Toros Roslin in the Context of the Cultural Relations of Cilician Armenia of the 13th century" 2 |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = 1 Dissertation, [[Georgian Academy of Sciences]], 1982.
2 Dissertation, Institute of the Art of the Ministry of Culture of Russia, Moscow, 2001. }} '''Levon Chookaszian''' ({{lang-hy|Լևոն Բաբկենի Չուգասզյան}}, born April 9, 1952) is an [[Armenians|Armenian]] [[art historian]] and the [[UNESCO]] Chair of Armenian Art History (UNESCO CAAH).[http://portal.unesco.org/education/en/ev.php-URL_ID=1589&URL_DO=DO_PRINTPAGE&URL_SECTION=201.html Profile of Chookaszian at UNESCO Education]. [[UNESCO]]. Accessed September 21, 2008. He is also currently the Head of Chair of History and Theory of Armenian Art at [[Yerevan State University]].[http://www.ysu.am/site/index.php?lang=2&page=3&p_num=&id=9 Faculty of History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110531153129/http://www.ysu.am/site/index.php?lang=2&page=3&p_num=&id=9 |date=2011-05-31 }}. [[Yerevan State University]]. Accessed September 21, 2008. Professor Chookaszian has delivered numerous lectures, particularly on [[medieval]] Armenian art, at universities in the former [[Soviet Union]], [[Europe]], and the [[United States]] and taught courses on Armenian art at [[UCLA]].Mamigonian, Marc A. "[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-79124909.html Prof. Levon Chookaszian Speaks on Early Armenian Christian Art]". ''The Armenian Reporter''. April 6, 2002. Retrieved September 21, 2008.Tiftick, Caitlin. "[http://armenianstudies.csufresno.edu/hye_sharzhoom/vol28/dec06/chookaszian_lec_2.aspx Kazan Visiting Professor Levon Chookaszian Gives His Second Lecture On Armenian Art] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081010130547/http://armenianstudies.csufresno.edu/hye_sharzhoom/vol28/dec06/chookaszian_lec_2.aspx |date=2008-10-10 }}". [[Fresno State University|Fresno State University Armenian Studies Program]]. December 2006, Vol. 28, No. 2 (96). Accessed September 21, 2008.Aivazian, Gia. "[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-105675535.html Levon Chookaszian to Teach at UCLA, Give Public Lecture Series]." ''The Armenian Reporter''. January 22, 2005. Retrieved July 5, 2009. He has authored dozens of articles and essays, many on the life of Armenian miniaturist [[Toros Roslin]], which have been published in scholarly journals, including ''[[Patma-Banasirakan Handes]]'', ''Banber Yerevani Hamalsarani'', ''[[Handes Amsorya]]'', ''Wiener Jahrbuch fur Kunstgeschichte'' and ''[[Revue des Études Arméniennes]]''. ==Selected bibliography== *{{hy icon}} "Կիրակոս Ծաղկող (The Painter Kirakos)." ''Usanoghakan Gitakan Asxatank'ner''. vol. 17, 1975. *{{hy icon}} "Մատենադարանի № 5576 ձեռագրի դրվագված կազմի մասին" ("On the Chased Binding of Manuscript № 5576 at the [[Matenadaran]]"). ''[[Patma-Banasirakan Handes]]''. № 2, 1978. *{{hy icon}} "Գրիգոր Ծաղկողի «Աստվածամոր Նինջը» մանրանկարը" ("The Miniature 'The Dormition of the Virgin' of Grigor Tsaghkogh"). ''Patma-banasirakan Handes''. № 4, 1979. *{{de icon}} "Rubens und die Armenier." Wiener Jahrbuch fur Kunstgeschichte,Bd. XXXII, 1979, Wien-Koln-Graz, pp. 41–48. *{{ru icon}} "Творчества Тороса Рослина И Византийская Монументальая Живопись" ("The Art of T'oros Roslin and Byzantine Monumental Painting"). ''Banber Yerevani Hamalsarani''. №. 3, 1989 *"On a Portrait of [[Leo II, King of Armenia|Prince Levon]] and [[Keran, Queen of Armenia|Princess Keran]]." ''Journal of Armenian Studies''. vol. vi. № 2, 2000-2001. *{{fr icon}} "L’Ouvre de T’oros Roslin et l’enluminure Byzantine." ''[[Revue des Études Arméniennes]]''. Tome 28, Paris, 2001–2002, pp. 399–424. *"The Motif of the Sphinx in the Decoration of manuscripts Illuminated by T'oros Roslin" in ''Between Paris and Fresno, Armenian Studies in Honor of Dickran Kouymjian''. Barlow Der Mugrdechian (ed.) (Armenian Studies Series, #13). Costa Mesa, CA: Mazda Publishers, 2008. ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060824090334/http://armenianstudies.csufresno.edu/ArmeniaDigitalProject/index.html Life and works of Toros Roslin by Levon Chookaszian]. The following is a '''list of Silesian language books in standard orthography'''. On August 10, 2009, standard [[orthography]] for writing in the [[Silesian language]] was adopted in [[Cieszyn]], at a meeting of the [[Standard language|Standardization]] Committee of the Silesian Language.<ref>Kanōna szrajbowanio ślōnskij godki (pp 1-9). 2009. ''Ślůnsko Nacyjo''. No 8(30), August. [[Zabrze]]: Ślōnsko Nacyjno Ôficyna. ISSN 1897-1717; http://www.dursmlodzi.org/slonsko-godka-w-pismie-pierwszy-darmowy-kurs-pisania-po-slasku/ ; https://www.facebook.com/standaryzacjaslonskijgodki/ ; Jolanta Tambor. 2010. Propozycje kodyfikacji ortograficznej śląszczyzny [Proposals on How to Codify the Spelling of the Silesian Language] (pp 83-92). ''Socjolingwistyka'', Vol 22-23. https://socjolingwistyka.ijp-pan.krakow.pl/images/mag_nr/nr_22_23.pdf; Kallus, Bogdan. 2015. ''Słownik gōrnoślōnskij gŏdki. Słownik górnośląsko-polski oraz polsko-górnośląski'' [The Dictionary of the Upper Silesian Language: Polish-Upper Silesian and Upper Silesian-Polish]. Chorzów: Pro Loquele Silesian, Towarzystwo Kultywowania i Promowania Mowy Śląskiej, pp 9-12.</ref> This orthographic standard is used, alongside another,<ref>[[:szl:Wikipedyjo:Prawidła zapisowańo|Wikipedyjo:Prawidła zapisowańo]]</ref> in the [[Silesian Wikipedia]].<ref>[[:szl:Wikipedyjo:Ślabikŏrzowy szrajbōnek|Wikipedyjo:Ślabikŏrzowy szrajbōnek]]</ref> Thus far, the majority of Silesian-language books in this standard orthography have been brought out by the [[Silesian National Publishing House]] and [[Silesia Progress]]. Between 2009 and 2018, 45 volumes were published in this standard orthography.

Capivara National Park|Serra da Capivara]] |position=left}} }} The [[UNESCO|United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] (UNESCO) [[World Heritage site]]s are places of importance to [[cultural heritage|cultural]] or [[natural heritage]] as described in the UNESCO World Heritage Convention, established in 1972.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/convention/ |title=The World Heritage Convention |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=21 September 2010}} The [[Brazil|Federative Republic of Brazil]] accepted the convention on 1 September 1977, making its historical sites eligible for inclusion on the list. As of 2017, there are 21 World Heritage sites in Brazil, including fourteen cultural sites and seven natural sites.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/br/ |title=Brazil |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=28 September 2017}} The first site in Brazil, the [[Ouro Preto|Historic Town of Ouro Preto]], was inscribed on the list at the 4th Session of the [[World Heritage Committee]], held in [[Paris]], [[France]] in 1980.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/repcom80.htm#124 |title= Report of the Rapporteur|publisher=UNESCO |date=29 September 1980 |accessdate=12 July 2014}} In 1983, [[Jesuit Missions]] of the [[Guaraní people|Guaranis]] was accepted to the list in a joint bid with [[Argentina]], making it Brazil's first trans-border property.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/repcom83.htm#275 |title=Report of the 7th Session of the Committee |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=13 August 2016}} [[Iguaçu National Park]] was enlisted in 1986 as the first site selected for its natural significance.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/repcom86.htm#355 |title=Report of the 10th Session of the Committee |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=13 August 2016}} Brazil's latest contribution to the World Heritage List, the [[Valongo Wharf|Valongo Wharf Archaeological Site]], was inscribed in 2017. In addition to its inscribed sites, Brazil also maintains twenty-three properties on its tentative list. ==World Heritage sites== The table is sortable by column by clicking on the [[File:Sort both.gif]] at the top of the appropriate column; alphanumerically for the site, area, and year columns; by state party for the location column; and by criteria type for the criteria column. Transborder sites sort at the bottom. :'''Site'''; named after the World Heritage Committee's official designation{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list |title=World Heritage List |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} :'''Location'''; at city, regional, or provincial level and geocoordinates :'''Criteria'''; as defined by the World Heritage Committee{{Cite web|title=The Criteria for Selection |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}} :'''Area'''; in [[hectare]]s and [[acre]]s. If available, the size of the buffer zone has been noted as well. (ix)(x) | {{convert|111930|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1999 | The site comprises some of the last remaining [[Atlantic Forest]]s and shows a very high diversity with many rare and endemic species. As such it is of high interest both for scientists and for conservation.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/892|title=Discovery Coast Atlantic Forest Reserves |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Historic Center (Salvador)|Historic Centre]] of [[Salvador, Bahia|Salvador de Bahia]] | [[File:Salvador-CCBY-2.jpg|150x150px|alt=Large three-storied buildings with facades painted in bright colors: light blue and yellow.]] | Brazil[[Bahia]]
{{coord|12|58|00|S|38|30|00|W|type:landmark|name=Historic Centre of Salvador de Bahia}} | Cultural:BraHisSal
(iv)(vi) | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" | 1985 | The colonial old town of the first Brazilian capital and town of the first slave market in the New World, has preserved a large number of brightly colored Renaissance houses decorated with stucco work from the 16th to 18th centuries.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/309|title=Historic Centre of Salvador de Bahia |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | Historic Centre of [[São Luís, Maranhão|São Luís]] | [[File:Reviver.JPG|150x150px|alt=A cobblestone street of old single-storied brightly colored houses.]] | Brazil[[Maranhão]]
{{coord|2|30|51|S|44|18|09|W|type:landmark|name=Historic Centre of Salvador de Bahia}} | Cultural:BraHisSao
(iii)(iv)(v) | {{convert|67|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1997 | São Luís has preserved the complete rectangular town plan and a large number of historical buildings making it a prime example of a Portuguese colonial town.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/821|title=Historic Centre of São Luís |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | Historic Centre of the Town of [[Diamantina, Minas Gerais|Diamantina]] | [[File:Igreja Matriz, Diamantina.jpg|150x150px|alt=Old church, cobble stone streets and two-storied houses with white facades.]] | Brazil[[Minas Gerais]]
{{coord|18|40|00|S|43|36|00|W|type:landmark|name=Historic Centre of the Town of Diamantina}} | Cultural:BraHisDia
(ii)(iv) | {{convert|29|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1999 | A well-preserved example of Baroque architecture, this 18th-century colonial town was founded in an inhospitable environment of rocky mountains and became a center of diamond mining in the 18th and 19th centuries.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/890|title=Historic Centre of the Town of Diamantina |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | Historic Centre of the Town of [[Goiás, Goiás|Goiás]] | [[File:Boamorte.jpg|150x150px|alt=Facade of a two-storied stone church, largely painted white/beige with red/brownish window frames.]] | Brazil[[Goiás]]
{{coord|15|56|00|S|50|08|00|W|type:landmark|name=Historic Centre of the Town of Goiás}} | Cultural:BraHisGoi
(ii)(iv) | {{convert|40|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2001 | Founded in 1727 by the [[bandeirante]] explorer Bartolomeu Bueno da Silva, Goiás has preserved much of its colonial heritage and is an example of a European settlement in the interior of South America.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/993|title=Historic Centre of the Town of Goiás |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | Historic Centre of the Town of [[Olinda]] | [[File:Mosteiro de São Bento - Olinda - Pernambuco - Brasil.jpg|150x150px|alt=White stone church with red tile roof near the sea.]] | Brazil[[Pernambuco]]
{{coord|8|00|48|S|34|50|42|W|type:landmark|name=Historic Centre of the Town of Olinda}} | Cultural:BraHisOli
(ii)(iv) | {{convert|120|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1982 | Founded in 1537 the town prospered as a centre of sugar-cane production. Following looting by the Dutch in the 17th century, the historic centre dates largely to the 18th century with a harmonious combination of buildings, gardens, churches, convents and chapels.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/189|title=Historic Centre of the Town of Olinda |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | Historic Town of [[Ouro Preto]] | [[File:Ouro Preto November 2009-7.jpg|150x150px|alt=Two-storied white buildings with red roof tiles lining a square. At the end of the square there is a prominent building with a clock tower.]] | Brazil[[Minas Gerais]]
{{coord|20|23|20|S|43|30|20|W|type:landmark|name=Historic Town of Ouro Preto}} | Cultural:BraHisOur
(i)(iii) | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" | 1980 | The prosperity of the town as the center of the Brazilian gold rush in the 18th century is reflected in a large number of preserved churches, bridges and fountains many of them designed by the Baroque sculptor [[Aleijadinho]].{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/124|title=Historic Town of Ouro Preto |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Iguaçu National Park]] | [[File:Cataratas do Iguaçu 0 2.jpg|150x150px|alt=A large horseshoe shaped waterfall.]] | Brazil[[Paraná (state)|Paraná]]
{{coord|25|41|00|S|54|26|00|W|type:landmark|name=Iguaçu National Park}} | Natural:BraIgu
(vii)(x) | {{convert|170086|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1986 | Together with Iguazú National Park on the Argentinian side, the park protects [[Iguazu Falls]], one of the world's largest waterfalls, and is home to many rare and endangered species such as [[giant anteater]] or the [[giant otter]]. The site had been listed as [[World Heritage in Danger|endangered]] 1999–2001 due to an illegally opened road through the park, dams on the [[Iguazu River]] and helicopter flights.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/355|title=Iguaçu National Park |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}} |-style="background-color: #D0E7FF" ! scope="row" | [[Jesuit Missions]] of the [[Guarani people|Guaranis]]: [[San Ignacio Miní]], [[Nuestra Señora de Santa Ana|Santa Ana]], [[Nuestra Señora de Loreto]] and [[Reducción de Santa María la Mayor, Argentina|Santa María Mayor]] (Argentina), Ruins of [[São Miguel das Missões]] (Brazil) | [[File:Ruinas de Sao Miguel das Missoes.jpg|150x150px|alt=Ruins of a stone church facade and tower.]] | Brazil[[Rio Grande do Sul]]
''also'' [[Misiones Province]], [[Argentina]]
{{coord|28|32|36|S|54|15|57|W|type:landmark|name=Jesuit Missions of the Guaranis: San Ignacio Mini, Santa Ana, Nuestra Señora de Loreto and Santa Maria Mayor (Argentina), Ruins of Sao Miguel das Missoes (Brazil)}} | Cultural:BraJes
(iv) | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" | 1983Extended in 1984 to include the four Argentinian missions making it a trans-border site; and name change from ''The Ruins of São Miguel das Missões'' to the present name. | Each of the five ruined Spanish Jesuit missions founded amidst a tropical forest in the land of the [[Guaraní people]] in the 17th and 18th centuries is characterized by a specific design.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/275|title=Jesuit Missions of the Guaranis: San Ignacio Mini, Santa Ana, Nuestra Señora de Loreto and Santa Maria Mayor (Argentina), Ruins of Sao Miguel das Missoes (Brazil) |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 September 2011}}
{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/repcom84.htm#291|title=Jesuit Missions of the Guaranis |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 September 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Pampulha Modern Ensemble]] | [[File:Igreja de São Francisco de Assis - Lagoa da Pampulha.jpg|150x150px|alt=White modernist building in front of a lake.]] | Brazil[[Minas Gerais]]
{{coord|19|51|07|S|43|58|25|W|type:landmark|name=Pampulha Modern Ensemble}} | Cultural:BraPam
(i)(ii)(iv) | {{convert|154|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2016 | The listed site consists of an urban project created in 1940 at Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais. It was designed around an artificial lake, [[Lake Pampulha]], and includes a casino, a ballroom, the Golf Yacht Club and the [[Church of Saint Francis of Assisi]]. The buildings were designed by the architect [[Oscar Niemeyer]], in collaboration with the landscape architect [[Roberto Burle Marx]] and Brazilian [[Modernism|Modernist]] artists.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1493|title=Pampulha Modern Ensemble |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=17 July 2016}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Pantanal]] Conservation Area | [[File:Pantanal, south-central South America 5170.jpg|150x150px|alt=Plain with forests, grassland, rivers and many lakes.]] | Brazil[[Mato Grosso]] and [[Mato Grosso do Sul]]
{{coord|17|43|00|S|57|23|00|W|type:landmark|name=Pantanal Conservation Area}} | Natural:BraPan
(vii)(ix)(x) | {{convert|187818|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2000 | The site contains four protected areas, encompassing one of the world's largest freshwater wetland ecosystems, and is home to an abundant number and diverse range of species.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/999|title=Pantanal Conservation Area |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=13 August 2016}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Rio de Janeiro]]: Carioca Landscapes Between the Mountain and the Sea | [[File:Christ on Corcovado mountain.JPG|150x86px|alt=Human sculptures and a hyperbolic shaped modern building with white ribs and glass.]] | Brazil[[Rio de Janeiro (state)|Rio de Janeiro]]
{{coord|22|56|52|S|43|17|29|W|type:landmark|name=Rio de Janeiro: Carioca Landscapes between the Mountain and the Sea}} | Cultural:BraRio
(v)(vi) | {{convert|7249|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2012 | The listed site consists of an exceptional urban setting rather than built heritage. It encompasses the key natural elements that have shaped and inspired the development of the city: from the highest points of the [[Tijuca National Park]]’s mountains down to the sea. They also include the [[Jardim Botânico do Rio de Janeiro|Botanical Gardens]], established in 1808, [[Corcovado|Corcovado Mountain]] with its celebrated [[Christ the Redeemer (statue)|statue of Christ]] and the hills around [[Guanabara Bay]], including the extensive designed landscapes along [[Copacabana (Rio de Janeiro)|Copacabana Bay]] which have contributed to the outdoor living culture of this spectacular city. Rio de Janeiro is also recognized for the artistic inspiration it has provided to musicians, landscapers and urbanists.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1100 |title=Rio de Janeiro: Carioca Landscapes between the Mountain and the Sea |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=2 July 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Congonhas|Sanctuary of Bom Jesus do Congonhas]] | [[File:Sanctuary of Bom Jesus do Congonhas.jpg|150x150px|alt=Stairs leading to a white stone church with two towers. Sculptures are placed on walls in front of the church.]] | Brazil[[Minas Gerais]]
{{coord|20|29|59|S|43|51|28|W|type:landmark|name=Sanctuary of Bom Jesus do Congonhas}} | Cultural:BraSan
(i)(iv) | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" | 1985 | Built in the 18th century, the site features a church, an outdoor stairway and seven chapels, decorated with statues by [[Aleijadinho]].{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/334|title=Sanctuary of Bom Jesus do Congonhas |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=13 August 2016}} |- ! scope="row" | [[São Francisco Square]] in the Town of [[São Cristóvão]] | [[File:Flickr - Ministério da Cultura - Praça São Francisco - São Cristóvão (SE) (6).jpg|150x150px|alt=White church on a square.]] | Brazil[[Sergipe]]
{{coord|11|00|58|S|37|12|36|W|type:landmark|name=São Francisco Square in the Town of São Cristóvão}} | Cultural:BraSao
(ii)(iv) | {{convert|3|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2010 | The square is surrounded by two churches, a palace and other buildings of different historical periods, exemplifying Franciscan architecture in north-eastern Brazil.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1272|title=São Francisco Square in the Town of São Cristóvão |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=13 August 2016}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Serra da Capivara National Park]] | [[File:Serra da Capivara - Painting 7.JPG|150x150px|alt=Rock painting in red of a four legged animal, a smaller four legged animal and a human figure.]] | Brazil[[Piauí]]
{{coord|8|25|00|S|42|20|00|W|type:landmark|name=Serra da Capivara National Park}} | Cultural:BraSer
(iii) | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" | 1991 | The site is among the oldest human communities in South America, featuring a great number of cave paintings, some dating as early as 25,000 years ago.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/606|title=Serra da Capivara National Park |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=13 August 2016}} |- !scope="row" | [[Valongo Wharf|Valongo Wharf Archaeological Site]] |[[File:Cais do Valongo e da Imperatriz.jpg|150x150px]] |Brazil[[Rio de Janeiro]]
{{Coord|22|53|49.6|S|43|11|14.62|W}} |CulturalBraRio
(vi) | {{convert|0.3895|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} |align="center" | 2017 |It is in the former harbour area of Rio de Janeiro in which the old stone wharf was built for the landing of enslaved Africans reaching the South American continent from 1811 onwards. An estimated 900,000 Africans arrived in South America via Valongo.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1548/|title=Valongo Wharf Archaeological Site|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2017-07-09}} |} ===Tentative list=== {{Update|section|reason=new sites have been added to the tentative list since 2014|date=March 2018}} In addition to sites inscribed on the World Heritage list, member states can maintain a list of tentative sites that they may consider for nomination. '''Marina Blagojević''' (also, '''Marina Šijaković-Blagojević''' and '''Marina Blagojević Hughson'''; born 1958)<ref name=filfak>{{cite web|script-title=sr:Билтен нових књига за 2012. годину|url=http://www.filfak.ni.ac.rs/biblioteka/bilteni/2012.html|work=filfak.ni.ac.rs|publisher=Филозофски факултет у Нишу|accessdate=24 May 2014|language=Serbian}}</ref> is a [[Serbian people|Serbian]] [[sociologist]], gender scholar, gender expert, and feminist.
==Biography== Blagojević received her education at the [[University of Belgrade]] (Bachelors, 1982; Masters, 1989; Ph.D. 1990).<ref name=aegee.org>{{cite web|title=Marina Blagojevic|url=http://www.projects.aegee.org/kosovo/conference/people/blagojevic.html|work=Kosovo, Understanding the Past, Looking Ahead|publisher=AEGEE (Association des États Généraux des Étudiants de l’Europe)|accessdate=24 May 2014}}</ref> In 1990, along with Vesna Gojkovic, Maja Korac, Andjelka Milic, Zarana Papic, and Lina Vuskovic, Blagojević founded Zenska Stranka (ZEST; "Women's Party"), a women's political party.<ref name=Cockburn1991>{{cite journal|last=Cockburn|first=Cynthia|title=A Women's Political Party for Yugoslavia: Introduction to the Serbian Feminist Manifesto|journal=Feminist Review|date=Autumn 1991|volume=39|pages=155–160|jstor=1395452|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan Journals|doi=10.1057/fr.1991.53}}</ref> In 1991, along with other members of the feminist activist group "Women and Society", Blagojević co-founded and served on the first board of the Women’s Study Center in Belgrade, Yugoslavia.<ref name=zenskestudie.edu.rs>{{cite web|title=Center’s History|url=http://www.zenskestudie.edu.rs/en/about-us/center-s-history|work=zenskestudie.edu.rs|accessdate=24 May 2014}}</ref> From 1994 through 1998, she was the initiator and organizer of the first feminist conference in Post-communist Countries (organized by Women's Study Center, Belgrade); in 1998, she was the initiator and organizer of the first [[NGO]] Forum in Serbia (organized by Democratic Center Foundation).
A past-president of the Sociological Association of Serbia, she is a scientific counselor at the Institute for Criminological and Sociological Research in [[Belgrade]], as well as a director at Altera MB Research Center on Gender and Ethnicity in [[Budapest]], Hungary. Blagoǰević has taught at [[Sarajevo University]] and [[Central European University]],<ref name=Harrison2011>{{cite web|last=Harrison|first=Katherine|title=Blagojevic, Marina. Postdoc|url=http://www.genderexcel.org/?q=node/183|publisher=Centre of Gender Excellence (GEXcel), at the inter-university Institute of Thematic Gender Studies, Linköping University & Örebro University|accessdate=24 May 2014|date=23 March 2011}}</ref> and in 2014, she is a Visiting Professor at the [[University of Graz]]. Her work as an international gender expert has been across various organizations, such as the [[European Commission]], [[European Parliament]], [[United Nations Development Programme]], [[UN Women]], [[United Nations Development Programme]], [[Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency|Sida]], and the [[International Fund for Agricultural Development]].<ref name=uni-graz.at>{{cite web|title=Gender Equality Promotion in the South Caucasus: What Could be Learned from the Balkans?|url=https://russian-east-european-eurasian-studies.uni-graz.at/en/news/detail/article/gender-equality-promotion-in-the-south-caucasus/|work=15 April 2014|publisher=University of Graz|accessdate=24 May 2014}}</ref> She has published more than 100 academic and 20 expert publications.
She is married to John Hughson, Professor of Sport and Cultural Studies and Director of the International Football Institute at the [[University of Central Lancashire]], UK.
==Selected works== * 2009, ''Knowledge production at the semiperiphery : a gender perspective''

{{About|the Middle East studies scholar|the economics professor|Michael Hudson (economist)|the investigative journalist|Michael Hudson (reporter)}}
[[File:Michael C. Hudson.jpg|thumbnail|Professor Michael C. Hudson]]
'''Michael Craig Hudson''' (born 2 June 1938) is an American political scientist, the Director of the Middle East Institute and Professor of Political Science at the [[National University of Singapore]]. He is also Professor Emeritus at [[Georgetown University]], where he was Professor of International Relations since 1979 and Saif Ghobash Professor of Arab Studies since 1980 in the [[Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service]]. While at Georgetown, Hudson served as Director of the [[Center for Contemporary Arab Studies]] intermittently for over twenty years, most recently from 2007 to 2010.<ref>[http://ccas.georgetown.edu/story/1242688381468.html Center for Contemporary Arab Studies story] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625144227/http://ccas.georgetown.edu/story/1242688381468.html |date=2013-06-25 }}</ref>
==Education== Michael C. Hudson received his Bachelor of Arts from [[Swarthmore College]] in 1959 and his Master of Arts and Ph.D. in Political Science from [[Yale University]] in 1960 and 1964, respectively. In 1961, he received a Certificate in Arabic from [[Princeton University]]. While studying for his PhD at Yale, Hudson specialized in comparative politics and international relations with his advisor, the renowned political scientist [[Karl W. Deutsch]]. His dissertation was entitled "Political Change in Lebanon: 1943-1963," which would be the basis for his first book ''The Precarious Republic: Political Modernization in Lebanon''.<ref>Michael C. Hudson, [http://michaelchudson.com/about/ "About"]</ref>
==Career== While conducting fieldwork in Lebanon for his doctoral dissertation, Hudson taught history at the American Community School in Beirut from 1962-1963. Also while completing his doctoral degree, he served as an instructor at Swarthmore College, from 1963-1964. Upon completing his studies at Yale University, Hudson became Assistant Professor at [[Brooklyn College]] at the [[City University of New York]], from 1964-1968, and then an Associate Professor (tenured), from 1968-1970. In 1970, he became Associate Professor in the [[School of Advanced International Studies]] (SAIS) at the [[Johns Hopkins University]]. He remained at SAIS until 1975, when he co-founded the Center for Contemporary Arab Studies (CCAS) at Georgetown University with a distinguished group of academics, including [[Hisham Sharabi]], John Ruedy, [[Ibrahim Oweiss]], Ambassador Clovis Maksoud, and Dean [[Peter F. Krogh]]. Hudson served as the director of CCAS from 1976-1989, and directed it again in 2000, 2003-2006, and 2007-2010.<ref>Center for Contemporary Arab Studies [http://www.mei.nus.edu.sg/about-mei/staff/research "Academics"]</ref>
In 2010, Hudson became the Director of the Middle East Institute (MEI) and Professor of Political Science at the National University of Singapore (NUS). Hudson was the first director of MEI, which was founded in 2007 as an autonomous research institute within NUS. He continues to direct MEI today. Hudson is also Professor Emeritus at Georgetown University.<ref>Middle East Institute, National University of Singapore [http://www.mei.nus.edu.sg/about-mei/staff/research "About MEI"]</ref>
In January 2015, he was appointed as the Kuwait Foundation Visiting Scholar at Harvard Kennedy School's [http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/project/64/middle_east_initiative.html Middle East Initiative]. He is leading a study group at the Kennedy School on "Rethinking the Arab State: The Collapse of Legitimacy in Arab Politics." <ref>[http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/project/64/middle_east_initiative.html "Middle East Initiative"]</ref>
During the course of his career, Hudson has served on numerous boards and committees related to the fields of political science and Middle East studies. He was a founding member of the [[Middle East Studies Association of North America]], and served as President of the association from 1986-87. He has served on the editorial boards of the International Journal of Middle East Studies, the Journal of Arab Affairs, and Cambridge University Press's "Middle East Library" series. He has also served as a manuscript evaluator for over a dozen academic journals. He was a member of the Advisory Board of the National Council on US-Arab Relations and the Board of Trustees of the American Institute for Pakistan Studies. Furthermore, he has served as an external evaluator for Middle East studies programs at the University of Utah, the University of Virginia, and Kuwait University. He has also served on committees within the Social Science Research Council and the American Council of Learned Societies.
==Academic Work== In addition to his distinguished record of establishing and directing premier centers for Middle East studies (CCAS and MEI), Hudson has been an authoritative scholar of contemporary Middle East politics. His most notable contributions are on the problem of political legitimacy in the Arab world, as set out in his seminal work ''Arab Politics: The Search for Legitimacy''.<ref>''Arab Politics: The Search for Legitimacy''. New Haven: Yale University Press, 1977.</ref> He has identified and explored the legitimacy 'deficits' of various Arab governments, focusing on cultural, institutional, and leadership sources of legitimacy. He argues that the question of participation is key to legitimacy, an issue borne out by the Arab uprisings beginning in 2011.<ref>“Awakening, Cataclysm, or Just a Series of Events? Reflections on the Current Wave of Protest in the Arab World,” in ''The Dawn of the Arab Uprisings: End of an Old Order?'' edited by Bassam Haddad, Rosie Bsheer and Ziad Abu-Rish, London: Pluto Press, 2012.</ref> Further, new information technologies and social media have invigorated civil societies in these countries.<ref>For example: “Information Technology, International Politics and Political Change in the Arab World,” ''Bulletin of the Royal Institute for Inter-Faith Studies'' (Amman, Jordan) 4:2 (Autumn/Winter 2002).</ref>
Hudson has also contributed to the scholarship on politics in divided societies, U.S. foreign policy in the Middle East, and regional integration and conflict in the Middle East. On politics in divided societies, he has taken Lebanon as an ongoing case study (see his book ''The Precarious Republic''), critiquing the theory of consociationalism and advocating the deconstruction rather than the institutionalization of sectarianism in Lebanon and elsewhere in the region, despite the recent apparent resurgence of sectarian polarization.<ref>''The Precarious Republic: Political Modernization in Lebanon'', New York: Random House, 1968; a publication of the Harvard Center for International Affairs; reissued with new preface in 1985 by Westview Press, Boulder, CO.</ref> On U.S. foreign policy in the Middle East, Hudson contends that a [[Pax Americana]] for the Middle East is illusory, owing to the U.S.'s unbalanced approach to the Palestine-Israel conflict, the negative consequences of military interventions, and the failure to maintain [[soft power]] and capitalize on a legacy of good will.<ref>For example: “To Play the Hegemon: Fifty Years of US Policy Toward the Middle East.” ''Middle East Journal'', 50:3 (Summer 1996): 329-43.</ref> He asserts that "Imperial America" has been driven by dysfunctional domestic pressures and poor decision-making, and has lately suggested that the so-called "American decline" in the Middle East might not be a bad thing for all concerned. Dealing with questions of regional integration and conflict in the greater Middle East, Hudson has explored the interplay between 'rationalist' classical international relations theory approaches and 'sociological' approaches that focus on the domestic decision-making arena.<ref>For example: “Rethinking Political Culture Explanations of Arab Authoritarianism and Democratization,” in ''Political Liberalization and Democratization in the Arab World: Theoretical Perspectives'', edited by Bahgat Korany, Paul Noble, and Rex Brynen, Boulder: Lynne Rienner Publishers, 1995.</ref> Influenced in his academic training by [[Kenneth Waltz]] on the one hand and [[Karl W. Deutsch]] on the other, Hudson has argued against theoretical stovepiping; understanding integrative and conflict tendencies requires acknowledgement of Waltz's 'third image' approach as well as Deutsch's 'social mobilization approach.'<ref>For example: “Social Mobilization Theory and Arab Politics," in ''From National Development to Global Community: Essays in Honor of Karl W. Deutsch'', edited by Richard L. Merritt and Bruce M. Russett, London: Allen and Unwin, 1981.</ref>
As a professor at Georgetown University and elsewhere, Hudson has taught courses on comparative politics, international politics, comparative politics of the Middle East, Middle East international politics, Lebanese politics, Palestine and the Arab-Israeli conflict, an introduction to social science, networked cultures and networked politics, Yemeni politics, U.S. policy in the Middle East, and politics in divided societies. Hudson is frequently consulted by news organizations for interviews and guest appearances to discuss political developments in the Middle East. Furthermore, he regularly contributes to the media through opinion editorials and short essays. Some of these outlets include ''Al-Jazeera English'', ''Jadaliyya'', ''Foreign Policy'', Singapore's ''Middle East Insights'', ''The Washington Post'', Lebanon's ''The Daily Star'' and ''Al-Mustaqbal'', the ''International Herald Tribune'', and others.<ref>List of op-eds [http://michaelchudson.com/media-opinion/ "Media and Opinion"]</ref>
Much of Hudson's academic work has been supported by competitive grants and fellowships. These have included the Robert R. McCormick Fellowship from Yale University (1959–62), American Philosophical Society grants (1965 and 1968), the Harvard Center for International Affairs Fellowship (1965–66), a Guggenheim Fellowship (1975–76), and a Fulbright Senior Fellowship to Yemen in 1994. He has also been the recipient of various honors and awards for his academic and administrative contributions to Middle East studies, including the "Jere L. Bacharach Service Award" from the Middle East Studies Association in 2011.<ref>Middle East Studies Association [http://www.mesa.arizona.edu/awards/jere-bacharach-service.html#previous "Jere L. Bacharach Service Award"]</ref>

The '''Monarchomachs''' ({{lang-fr|Monarchomaques}}) were originally [[Early Modern France|French]] [[Huguenot]] [[political theory|theorists]] who opposed [[monarchism|monarchy]] at the end of the 16th century, known in particular for having theoretically justified [[tyrannicide]]. The term was originally a pejorative word coined in 1600 by the Scottish royalist and Catholic [[William Barclay (jurist)|William Barclay]] (1548–1608) from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] μόναρχος (''monarchos'' {{spaced ndash}} "monarch, sole ruler") and μάχομαι ("makhomai" {{spaced ndash}} the verb meaning "to fight"), meaning "those who fight against monarchs".
Born out of the [[French Wars of Religion]], they were most active between 1573, a year after the [[St. Bartholomew's Day massacre]], and 1584. The Monarchomachs pleaded in favour of a form of "[[popular sovereignty]]". Arguing for a sort of contract between the sovereign and the people, they have been considered as the precursors of [[social contract]] theories.<ref name=Gallica>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/themes/PolXVI6.htm Les Monarchomaques], ''[[Gallica]]'' {{fr icon}}</ref>
== Theory of tyrannicide ==
The Monarchomachs included jurists such as the Calvinists [[François Hotman]] (1524–1590), [[Théodore de Bèze]] (1519–1605), [[Simon Goulart]] (1543–1628), [[Nicolas Barnaud]] (1538–1604), [[Hubert Languet]] (1518–1581), [[Philippe de Mornay]] (1549–1623) and [[George Buchanan]] (1506–1582). Through the means of [[libel (poetry)|libels]] and theoretical tracts, they revived the doctrine of the [[tyrannicide]]. It had been opposed during the [[Middle Ages]] by the "legists" (jurists who theorized the royal power) who attempted to reserve the title of [[tyrant]] to those who tried to overturn the ruling monarch. Legists thus ended up legitimizing, under the name of "tyrannicide", the assassinations of political opponents ordered by the monarch.
Monarchomachs considered that the end of the [[Sovereign state|state]] was prosperity of the whole social group, as the true sovereign, granting effective practice of power to the king, whose authority remained of [[divine right of king|divine right]].<ref name=Gallica/> Exercise of popular sovereignty was to be delegated to the magistrates and the officers of the crown. They considered that the people were a collective body, possessed of a specific wisdom, which allowed them to understand better than the king the common good, distinct from the interest of each of its parties. Assimilated to the medieval ''[[wikt:universitas|universitas'',]] the people was thus considered as a legal subject, whose interests were represented by the [[French States-General|General Estates]].<ref>[http://www.memo.fr/dossier.asp?ID=1011 Memo.fr] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070507125351/http://www.memo.fr/dossier.asp?ID=1011 |date=2007-05-07 }} {{fr icon}}</ref><ref>[http://multitudes.samizdat.net/Un-pouvoir-constituant-pour-libres.html Un pouvoir constituant... pour libres professeurs ?] (on the book of Jean Fabien Spitz, ''[[John Locke]] et les fondements de la liberté moderne''), by François Matheron, ''[[Multitudes]]'', June 2002 {{fr icon}}</ref> This conception of the magistrates and the association of wise people as best representants of the people separated them from modern conception of [[democracy]], as they restricted effective power to a minority. [[Max Weber]] considered them in his lecture ''[[Politics as a Vocation]]'' as participants of the movement of [[rationalization (sociology)|rationalization]] of law in Europe.
The Monarchomachs also claimed that if the sovereign persecuted true religion, he would violate the contract concluded between God and the people, who were thus granted a [[right of rebellion]]. They were inspired by [[Aristotle]], [[Thomas Aquinas]], and the [[School of Salamanca]] on the killing of "bad kings". This legimitization of tyrannicide may have inspired as much the [[Jacques Clément|friar Clément]], who assassinated [[Henry III of France|Henry III]] in 1589, as [[François Ravaillac|Ravaillac]], who assassinated [[Henry IV of France|Henry IV]] in 1610.<ref>[http://www.lefigaro.fr/litteraire/20061130.FIG000000196_jacques_clement_avant_ravaillac.html Jacques Clément avant Ravaillac], ''[[Le Figaro]]'', 30 November 2006 {{fr icon}}</ref> Rebellion against tyranny was considered not only as necessary, but as a divine right.
== Monarchomach theory in the 16th century ==
The term ''Monarchomachs'' was coined by [[William Barclay (jurist)|William Barclay]]<ref name=Skinner>[[Quentin Skinner]], ''The Foundations of Modern Political Thought'', Cambridge University Press, 1978, p. 301.</ref> in his book ''De Regno et Regali Potestate'' (About the Powers of Authority and Royalty), published in 1600. Barclay's theory was that the Huguenots had lost their struggle with the Catholic Church and were turning their battle towards the government to undermine the king's support of the Catholics. Eventually, the term was used to classify anyone who was opposed to the king's rule.
At first a Protestant doctrine, the notion of tyrannicide was reappropriated by the Catholics when Protestants came to be kings. It was then used in [[French Revolution|revolutionary]] discourses during the debates concerning the execution of [[Louis XVI of France|Louis XVI]], while the right of rebellion was included in the 1789 [[Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen]].
Influenced by the Huguenots, some British thinkers also embraced the Monarchomaque movement.
